This award strives to conserve biodiversity and manage natural resources in ways that maintain their long-term viability and preserve their potential to meet the needs of present and future generations. Activities include combating illegal and corrupt exploitation of natural resources and the control of invasive species. This includes The Andean Bear (Tremarctos ornatus) is the only ursid found in South America, threatened by habitat fragmentation and conflict with humans, and categorized as vulnerable to extinction. Human-Andean Bear conflicts (HBCs) arise when farmers experience a loss with their crops or livestock leading to the automatic assumption that it is due to Andean Bears, often triggering retaliatory (illegal) hunting of this protected species. Andean Bears are mainly herbivores so livestock predation is unusual at best, and improved crop production methods can mitigate crop damage. This project will support conservation efforts for the Andean Bear in Peru by strengthening the capacity and knowledge of key stakeholders (Ministries of Environment and Agriculture and locally affected farmers) by developing effective measures to mitigate HBCs at a national level and applying them in local pilot areas. The Peruvian government has an Andean Bear Strategy but the implementation and monitoring of this strategy requires support. Specific project activities focus on improving the Peruvian government’s capacity to coordinate responses to HBCs on a national level and reducing HBC impact in at least three pilot sites through improved, alternative production techniques that support Andean Bear protection..

description.narrative: U.S. assistance builds the capacity of Peruvian institutions to combat transnational organized crime more effectively, improve citizen security and social inclusion, sustainably manage Peru's diverse and fragile environment, and expand the benefits of Peru's economic progress to more of its citizens. Peru is one of the world's largest cocaine producers, a major money laundering center, a principal source of illegally logged timber and illegally mined gold, and the largest source of counterfeit U.S. currency worldwide. While economic growth has slowed for the past two years due to a slump in international commodity prices and the failure to implement second generation reforms, successive Peruvian governments have pursued judicious, market-based economic policies yielding over a decade of economic growth averaging five percent, which has halved poverty rates, reduced infant mortality, increased lifespans, and expanded access to education. Peru is one of the United States' most steadfast democratic partners in the region, and the continuation of bi-lateral assistance advances U.S. national security and economic interests.
